awd_titl_txt: RI: Small: Collaborative Research: Why is Automating the Design of Robot Controllers Hard, and What Can Be Done About It
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to bring together new techniques for filtering and planning to improve reasoning and analysis steps employed during robot design.

By understanding those parts of the design process that are typically conducted by hand and by asking which parts can be practically automated, the research has the potential to assist practitioners by scaling up the problems tackled, optimizing systems automatically, and ultimately freeing designers from low-level detail and elevating their use of time.

por.por_cntn:
A lot of research (both ongoing and prior work) has explored algorithms to make robots more capable --- but the scope for improvement often depends on the particular robot being considered. This project, in contrast, examined a meta question: how algorithms could aid in the design of robots in order to help roboticists better understand which sensing, actuation, and computational resources are needed for a robot to perform given tasks. Over the duration of the project we introduced several innovations, including novel algorithms and new data representations that allow one to minimize various design costs or the resource requirements. But in so doing, we also showed that several key problems of relevance to robotics design problems are computationally difficult to solve optimally and, in some cases, even to give good approximate answers, at least under today's current understanding of complexity (e.g., the famous P vs. NP problem). In seeking to mitigate this challenge, part of the project examined how algorithms and a human designer might work in concert to explore the vast space of robot designs interactively. Though promising, owing to the intrinsic challenges involved,  our prototype implementation is only feasible for small scale problems.

It is worth highlighting one unexpected aspect of the project, which arose from seeking to understand not only standard sensors such as those that are widely available, but also abstract "hypothetical" sensors. A curious condition may arise when a robot is required to act in a way that preserves privacy: we may require that it plan and act so as to remain ignorant of certain sensitive information. Doing so demands sensors that have unusual and (we believe, previously overlooked) properties. During this project, the research team formalized the question of what information a sensor ought to provide even when there are stipulations that bound the amount a robot may know, and we then developed algorithms that are complete in that they can either eventually find a suitable sensor, or correctly report that none exists to satisfy the requirements posed.

As part of the project, the research team contributed to workshops that examined minimality and design automation. Part of that effort (along with several members of the community) solidified into "The Robot Design Game", an activity that has been effective for outreach in helping to illustrate the combinatorial challenges inherent in producing robot designs capable of achieving tasks.

More work remains to be done to improve the practicality of these algorithms and the ideas more generally, but the project has helped establish a useful base from which to explore computational tools for robot design.
